bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, April 15, 1901
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: No. 67. Consular. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, April 15, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill Assistant Secretary of State Washington.
Subject. A reply to your Consular despatch No. 32, Mar. 12, 1901
Synopsis. The irregularities, complained of were not known to the Chief of the Mission.
No. 67. Consular. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia; April 15, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt April 14, 1901, of your No. 32, "Consular," of March 12, 1901, in which I am reprimanded for the very irregular manner and careless way in which the Secretary of this Legation acknowledged the receipt of official publications &c sent to this Legation.
In reply, I have to say, I have often directed the Secretary to acknowledge the receipt of official publications sent to this Consulate Genral; whenever, he

he has reported the receipt of such to me; but have never directed him, knowing it, to be such, to acknowledge the receipt of any Diplomatic publication; the which I have been very careful to acknowledge myself. I exceedingly, regret that such errors and irregularities have served in this office. The preparation of his despatches, is such and other cases touching the business of the Legation are never presented to me for my approved; and I am sorry to have to say, that I am usually entirely ignorant of the contents thereof. If the Secretary of the Legation, was in reality a subordinate officer, in feelings; and not as he feels himself to be, my official equal and associate; coming in at will, and going out at pleasure; not being accountable to

to me; writing, publishing and sending forth any matter that he sees fit to write or publish, without consulting me; I would have a remedy, otherwise, I am powerless to prevent such errors, unless I do the entire work myself.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith, Consul General.
